w:r.w:t: TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC
1. Testing, adjusting, and balancing of air systems.
2. Testing, adjusting, and balancing of hydronic systems.
3. Measuring and reporting HVAC system performance.
1. Section 23 09 00 - Instrumentation and Control for HVAC.
3. ASHRAE/IES Standard 90.1 - Energy Standard for Buildings Except Low-Rise Residential Buildings.
1. AABC National Standards for Total System Balance.
1. NEBB Procedural Standards for Testing, Adjusting, and Balancing of Environmental Systems.
D. Sheet Metal and Air Conditioning Contractors' National Association (SMACNA):
1. SMACNA - HVAC Systems Testing, Adjusting, and Balancing.
E. Testing, Adjusting, and Balancing Bureau (TABB):
1. TABB International Standards for Environmental Systems Balance.
A. Testing: Determination of quantitative performance of equipment.
B. Adjusting: Regulation of fluid flow rates and electrical characteristics to achieve design performance.
C. Balancing: Proportional adjustment of system flows to achieve design or specified values.
D. Procedural Standards: AABC National Standards, NEBB Procedural Standards, or TABB International Standards.
E. Report Forms: AABC National Standards, NEBB Procedural Standards, or TABB International Standards report forms.
A. TAB Plan: Submit a written TAB plan prior to commencing work, including:
B. Draft Reports: Submit draft TAB reports for review prior to final reports.
C. Final Reports: Submit final TAB reports after completion and acceptance of all TAB work.
A. Qualification Data: For TAB firm and TAB supervisor.
B. Instrument Calibration Reports: Submit calibration certificates for all instruments used.
C. Field Reports: Progress reports during TAB work.
1. Certified by AABC, NEBB, or TABB.
2. Minimum 5 years experience in TAB work.
3. Experience with projects of similar size and complexity.
1. Certified by AABC, NEBB, or TABB.
2. Minimum 3 years experience as TAB supervisor.
1. Calibrate instruments within 6 months of TAB work.
A. Verify the following before beginning TAB work:
1. HVAC systems are complete and operational.
5. Electrical systems serving HVAC are energized.
6. Hydraulic systems are filled, vented, and flushed.
7. Pumps are operational and proper rotation verified.
A. Coordinate with installing contractors to ensure systems are complete.
B. Coordinate with controls contractor to ensure control sequences are operational.
C. Coordinate with Owner to schedule TAB work.
D. Notify Architect and Engineer minimum 5 working days prior to commencing TAB work.
A. Provide instruments required to perform TAB work, including:
B. Instrument Accuracy: As specified in AABC, NEBB, or TABB standards.
A. Verify systems are ready for TAB as described in Prerequisites.
B. Report deficiencies in writing to Contractor and Architect/Engineer.
C. Do not proceed with TAB until deficiencies are corrected.
A. Perform TAB in accordance with AABC, NEBB, or TABB procedural standards.
B. Perform preliminary system checks before adjusting and balancing.
C. Adjust systems to achieve design values within specified tolerances.
D. Mark final positions of all manual volume dampers, valves, and other adjustment devices.
E. Lock all balancing devices after final adjustment.
1. Measure and record fan performance data.
2. Traverse duct mains to establish total air quantities.
3. Adjust fan speeds as required to achieve design airflow.
5. Measure and adjust airflow at each outlet.
1. Measure airflow at each supply diffuser, register, and grille.
2. Measure airflow at each return and exhaust inlet.
3. Adjust to within plus or minus 10 percent of design airflow.
1. Measure outdoor airflow at design minimum position.
2. Verify economizer operation and measure airflow at full outdoor air.
3. Adjust to achieve design outdoor air quantities.
2. Measure and record pump performance data.
3. Adjust pump speed or impeller trim as required.
2. Compare with pump curves and adjust as required.
1. Measure flow rate at each coil or terminal unit.
2. Adjust balancing valves to achieve design flow.
3. Adjust to within plus or minus 10 percent of design flow.
1. Measure entering and leaving water temperatures at coils.
2. Calculate and verify heat transfer rates.
1. Supply, return, and exhaust fans: Plus or minus 10 percent of design airflow.
2. Air terminals: Plus or minus 10 percent of design airflow.
3. Outdoor air: Plus 10 percent, minus 0 percent of design airflow.
1. Pumps: Plus or minus 10 percent of design flow.
2. Terminal units: Plus or minus 10 percent of design flow.
3. Main piping: Plus or minus 5 percent of design flow.
1. Dry bulb: Plus or minus 1 degree F.
2. Wet bulb: Plus or minus 1 degree F.
3. Water temperature: Plus or minus 0.5 degree F.
A. General: Prepare final TAB report in accordance with AABC, NEBB, or TABB standards.
1. Title page with project information and TAB firm certification.
9. Certification statement signed by TAB supervisor.
C. Submit 3 hard copies and 1 electronic copy (PDF format) of final report.
A. Owner reserves the right to verify TAB results by spot-checking.
B. If spot-check measurements differ from reported values by more than 10 percent, perform additional verification at no additional cost.
C. If additional verification confirms discrepancies, re-balance affected systems and re-submit reports at no additional cost.
